item.description:
Thanks to everyone that responded so favorably to our idea to hold Meetups for small groups with discussion/dinner at a place whose dining matches the quality of film.  

This is a work in progress.  Please know that we'll be offering as many meetups as always, open to everyone.  In addition, our hope is to see everyone in a setting that enables us to become more of a community.  

Our hope is to enjoy the company of every member of this group in a setting that enables you to know that your participation is valued, your opinion matters, and you have found a community that is on the same wavelength.

Our first effort is to go to the Hungry Mother after The Interrupters on Sunday, September 18.  Hungry Mother makes group reservations extremely difficult, and there was no way for us to get a larger group at any time that worked with the showing at the Kendall.

So, this event is only for 4, but in the future, maybe we get a second table?  Or, schedule a different night when the reservations can be for 6 or 8?  Again, a work in progress.

The Interrupters   

From producer/director Steve James (Hoop Dreams) and author-turned-producer Alex Kotlowitz (There Are No Children Here) comes an epic documentary work exploring violence in America. The film tells the moving and surprising story of three "violence interrupters" in Chicago who, with bravado, humility and even humor, try to protect their communities from the violence they once employed. Filmed over the course of a year, The Interrupters captures a period in Chicago when it became a national symbol for the violence in our cities. The film's main subjects work for an innovative organization, CeaseFire, which believes that the spread of violence mimics that of infectious diseases, and so the treatment should be similar: go after the most infected, and stop the infection at its source. These "violence interrupters" (their job title)—who have credibility on the street because of their own personal histories—intervene in conflicts before the incidents explode into violence. Their work and their insights are informed by their own journeys, which, as each of them points out, defy easy characterization.

HUNGRY MOTHER: http://www.hungrymothercambridge.com/

If we don't see you at this movie, we'll see you at another

Shirley and John
item.how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the lobby before the film.
item.name: Movie and a Dinner: The Interrupters and Hungry Mother
